Award.AwardTitle: Functional Genomics of Tomato Fruit Quality: Bridging the Gap between QTLs and Genes
Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Harry J. Klee (University of Florida - Gainsville)

CoPIs: Zhangjun Fei and James J. Giovannoni (Boyce Thompson Institute/USDA-ARS) and Denise Tieman (University of Florida - Gainsville)

Collaborator: Alisdair Fernie (Max Planck Institute of Molecular Plant Physiology, Potsdam-Golm, Germany)

Fruits are major components of the human diet, contributing a large portion of vitamins, minerals, antioxidants, and fiber. While flavor and nutrient composition have clear and profound human benefit, they are difficult traits to modify due to their complex metabolic and regulatory pathways. Synthesis of nutritional and flavor compounds is the result of coordinated activity of multiple biochemical pathways, requiring integration of developmental, physiological and environmental cues. Effective manipulation of these traits requires knowledge of the pathways and the regulatory systems that control them. This project exploits the exceptional diversity within the Solanaceae to identify networks regulating synthesis of flavor and nutrition compounds. For many metabolic pathways, all of the genes encoding biosynthetic activities are known. Yet virtually nothing is known about how those genes are regulated to control metabolic output. The focus of this project is on three specific metabolic pathways responsible for synthesis of major flavor and nutrition chemicals: synthesis of folic acid, carotenoids and a family of phenylalanine-derived flavor and fragrance volatiles. In each case multiple, as yet unidentified genetic loci regulating metabolite flux through these pathways have been identified from wild tomato relatives. This project will specifically identify the genes responsible for that regulation and their mechanisms of action. In order to most effectively accomplish these goals, several valuable community resources will be developed. Gene expression profiling of fruit from lines containing defined segments of the wild tomato relative, Solanum pennellii, will be performed, providing quantitative information for gene expression and gene mapping. Also, BAC end sequencing of a S. pennellii library will be performed, facilitating rapid isolation of orthologous sequences by the entire research community. All sequence data will be available through GenBank and all metabolite, gene expression, and SNP data will be accessible through the Tomato Functional Genomics Database (TFGD, www.ted.bti.cornell.edu). All clone and germplasm resources can be ordered online at http://ted.bti.cornell.edu/cgibin/TFGD/order/home.cgi.

This research project integrates genomics, metabolomics, informatics, genetics and biochemistry to achieve a deep understanding of how to manipulate important, multigenic quality traits in plants. This systems approach to a problem provides an excellent training environment for undergraduate and graduate students as well as postdoctoral scientists. The project integrates with ongoing highly successful minority training programs at both institutions. The achievable goals of better and healthier foods are highly appealing to students, industry and the public at large.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Genetic information is encoded in the DNA of an organism.  The epigenome defines aspects of how the DNA is chemically modified and packaged to regulate how and when genetic information is used.  Epigenome studies are prevalent especially as related to human disease.  We investigated the role of epigenome changes in tomato and discovered that they are essential to normal fruit development and ripening.  This discovery revealed the powerful role that epigenome changes can play in regulating development and suggest that important crop traits such as ripening can be better understood and ultimately improved if we understand their epigenome components.  Not only does epigenome modification (DNA methylation) control critical aspects of ripening, it also acts to modulate gene expression in response to stress. We demonstrated that chilling of a ripe fruit results in increased methylation that is correlated with reduced synthesis of flavor chemicals, reducing to a molecular level the age-old question of why chilling reduces flavor quality.

 

Understanding the genetic regulation of processes leading to fruit flavor and nutritional quality is essential for development of improved crop varieties.  We identified a gene responsible for a natural mutation that gives fruit more uniform coloration.  In doing so, we now understand that the number of chloroplasts in a fruit is directly related to both the amount of flavor-associated chemicals and carotenoids a fruit accumulates.  Carotenoids are strong antioxidants and precursors of vitamin A.  Knowledge of this gene and its variants found in tomato breeding lines will facilitate selection for more nutritious tomatoes.  This information can also be used to target similar genes that may confer similar effects in other fruit crops.  In the specific area of flavor, we identified multiple genes and pathways responsible for synthesis of important flavor volatiles. In particular, we established the pathways for synthesis and degradation of volatile esters. A particularly exciting cross-disciplinary discovery was that some volatile chemicals contribute to the perception of sweetness in a fruit. This discovery opens the possibility that foods can be made to taste sweeter with addition of substantially less sugars.

 

A key outcome of the project was contribution to the genome sequencing of the tomato wild relative Solanum pennellii.  This species can be readily hybridized with the cultivated tomato, S.  lycopersicum, and over the years has been the source of natural disease resistance and fruit color genes.  Completion of an accurate high quality genome of this species has already facilitated identification of numerous important genes for natural pathogen protection reducing pesticide use and a number of the fruit aroma and quality genes targeted under this project.

 

More broadly, we made significant contributions to training of undergraduate student interns, most of whom were underrepresented minorities, graduate students and postdoctoral associates. A key component of the project was a collaboration with California State University, Fresno that served as a pipeline for undergraduate interns. Co-PI Giovannoni visited annually for a seminar and to meet undergraduate students interested in summer internships.  Three Hispanic-American students Sabrina Romero, Brittany Soltero and Jessica Orozoco participated in this project as summer interns. In the last year Lance Courtney, undergraduate and US military veteran managed a field trial of IL lines in the California central valley and shipped fruit to BTI where he participated in carotenoid and RNA-seq analysis as an intern.  In parallel, a collaboration between Fort Valley State University, a historically black undergraduate institution, and the University of Florida resulted in training of 14 African-American students at the UF. The project resulted in training or several BTI postdocs and Ph.D. students.  Silin Zhong is now an Assistant Professor at the Chinese University of Hong Kong.  Nigel Gapper is Genomics Research and Development manager at Agrofresh Inc..  Cuong Nguyen and Ryan Mcquinn are now postdocs at the University of Florida and Australian National University, respectively. At UF, Melissa Mageroy was a PhD student who went on to do postdoctoral work at the University of British Columbia. Charles Goulet and Yusuke Kamiyoshihara were postdoctoral associates, now an Associate Professor at Lavall University and an Assistant Professor at Nihon University in Japan, respectively.

 

Finally, a large number of publications acknowledging NSF support appeared in journals including Science, Nature Biotechnology, Current Biology, The Plant Cell, The Plant Journal and Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.
